Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Cowan for his question. When the wharfies voted in Sydney for the agreement with Patrick, they were voting for a reduction in the manning levels in the Port Botany terminal. Just to give members an idea of the extent of the change, in Port Botany as they were voting, the manning levels were just over 320, and what they voted for was an ongoing manning level of 160. That is a very significant change. In one of the regional ports, for example, the manning levels have been over 30. After they voted yesterday, the manning levels will be fewer than 10 people. In terms of remuneration, when they voted, the average annual remuneration was around $90,000 a year. When they voted yesterday, they voted for annual salaries of $58,000. There will be some productivity bonus, but that is tied to achieving a reasonable rate which is in keeping the government's benchmark productivity rates. When implemented, the agreement will see Australia have internationally competitive benchmarks. Not only will we have internationally competitive benchmarks; we will also see the end of all the rorts and rip-offs which have been supported by the Labor Party in conjunction with the MUA for far too long. So when they sign up to that agreement they sign up to the abolition of the nick, to the abolition of double-headers-the infamous overtime rort which has seen such high income. They also sign up to the end of the order of pick. I refer to the order of pick because the independent Productivity Commission report singled out the order of pick as one of the real problems on the Australian waterfront. We have abolished all those things because we as a government have been publicly prepared to advocate and give leadership to fix up one of the most intractable problems in the Australian economy. The benefit for the Australian community is an increase in annual income-and therefore in living standards--of about $1 billion, and an extra 4,000 jobs. In fact, we had a report on that well before you wrote that letter to Mr Sharp yesterday, Prime Minister, which is indicative of the very extensive work we have done on the economic benefits of these sorts of reforms. In conclusion, one of the matters still before the parliament is the passage of the levy legislation so that this reform package will be paid for by the industry. The Labor Party has been opposed to it because the MUA was opposed to it. Now the MUA is in favour of it but they have been slow ringing the Labor Party, and so now we find that the Labor Party is reluctant to support the legislation. What an irony it is that the only thing standing between the wharfies and their money is the Labor Party. How do I know that in the end it will stand aside? I know-and I say it with absolute confidence-in the end, when it comes to the MUA requiring their dollars and the only thing to be done is to have the Labor Party set aside, what will the Labor Party do? It will do what it is told by the crane lift MUA as usual. Capital Gains Tax

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Has the Treasurer been asked by United States venture capital lobbyists to amend capital gains tax laws? Is capital gains tax treatment of exempt US pension funds wanting to invest in Australia inhibiting investments in our high technology companies? If so, what is the government's response?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I would not rule out my having been asked, although it has not come to the top of my attention in recent weeks. I receive numerous submissions and requests in relation to reducing taxes of various kinds, and I have no doubt that there would be lobbyists for venture capital funds who have made representations to me, my office or my department from time to time. You do hear the argument on quite a number of occasions-I have heard it-that a reduction in capital gains tax would help venture capital projects in Australia, but I point out that we already give considerable assistance to venture capital projects in Australia not only through pooled development funds but also through our business innovation funds and through a number of the measures which were actually outlined in the statement by the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism at the end of last year. I am not for a moment saying that everything about our tax system in the capital gains tax area is perfect; clearly there is a great of complexity. But the government has outlined the primary areas in which it believes tax reform would help the Australian public: the reform of indirect tax; a reform of personal income tax, particularly the impact of top marginal rates on average income earners; the interplay between the social security and income tax systems which penalise low income earners; and a reduction of complexity in relation to the business income tax system which is fraught with difficulty and complexity. As I have outlined, in accordance with the five principles that the Prime Minister laid down, they form the focus of the government's attention to tax reform. Job Network

Speaker: Mrs DRAPER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can the minister inform the House of progress with the implementation of the Job Network? Has the minister seen reports of a survey of Job Network members purporting to reflect the views of Job Network members? Is the minister aware of comments undermining the credibility of the report? Dr KEM'p-1 thank the member for Makin for her question. The Job Network is one of the most significant social reforms of the last 50 years. Although it is still in its very early days, I am pleased to be able to inform the House that the Job Network is already performing very well. There are many thousands of vacancies now being lodged every week with the Job Network. Indeed, there are more quality jobs now on the national job vacancy database than there ever were with the Commonwealth Employment Service. The most disadvantaged are proving to be particularly assisted by the Job Network. Some 40 per cent of job placements are for the long term unemployed. All job seekers are benefiting. Indeed, some 20 per cent of the total vacancies filled by members of the Job Network are going to people for whom the government is not paying a fee. Despite some very inaccurate press reports, which probably result from the campaign being waged by the Commonwealth Public deal Sector Union against the Job Network, the fact is that referrals from Centrelink are on target. My department is working with Centrelink to increase the number of referrals above target. Some members may have seen newspaper reports today about comments by an organisation called Jobs Australia, through Mr David Thompson, purporting to identify flaws in Job Network. Members of the House should know that many of the organisations associated with Jobs Australia are outraged by this report. They regard it as a poor report and quite inaccurate. One of these organisations that belongs to Jobs Australia is an organisation called Job Power. Job Power has written to me to say: We were approached to complete a Jobs Australia telephone survey regarding the provision of FLEX 3 services and elected not to do so. We felt the survey lacked any statement as to its aims and objectives and was poorly presented. It also requested information which was commercial-inconfidence. Other Job Network providers are very angry at the remarks thtlt were made by Mr Thompson maligning their operations. A media release issued by the Ballarat Community Education Centre said: The federal government's Job Network system is working extremely well, and negative comments surrounding the current report from Jobs Australia are inconsistent with reality. Our employment arm, Ballarat Employment Service and Training, has found the new system far more effective than previously existed under the old CES. Refenals to us from Centrelink have exceeded our expectations. Payments due to us have been paid promptly. One can only wonder at the motivating factors behind comments condemning a new employment system which in the experience of numerous providers is performing extraordinarily well. This government is committed to improving services in employment placement for employers and for unemployed people. The Job Network system is performing well on target. It is right on track. Already it is performing well ahead of the former CES, and I want to congratulate all those members of the Job Network for putting so much of a contribution into their local communities. Speaker: Mr NUGENT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the minister inform the House of the Australia government's reaction to Bishop Belo's meeting with President Habibie? Can the minister inform the House of the Australian government's position on developments in East Timor?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Aston for his question. I know he is one of the members of the House who is deeply concerned about the situation in East Timor and has followed the issue in a very mature and constructive way. The government welcomes the discussions that have taken place between President Habibie and Bishop Belo. These talks have, we believe, been very helpful in taking the issue of East Timor forward. The government has continuously argued since we were elected to office that we wanted to see a reduction in the military presence in East Timor, and to allow the people of East Timor a greater say in their own affairs. It is pleasing. therefore, that President Habibie has indicated he is prepared to reduce the number of troops in East Timor and to explore options for granting a greater degree of autonomy. East Timor is a deeply divided and troubled place. A satisfactory resolution to the probtax lems facing East Timor will require the development of a dialogue amongst the people of East Timor and, of course, with the government in Jakarta. Our experience in assisting with the Bougainville peace process shows that the people of a divided community can only be brought together through a process of patient dialogue. The Australian government does not think for a moment that simplistic solutions and slogans will solve delicate problems like that of East Timor.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: ADDITIONAL RESPONSES
text: Qn Tuesday, the member for Dickson asked whether the income Â·of a person's step-parent was taken into account in establishing eligibility for the youth allowance. I can confirm that a young person's entitlement to the youth allowance depends on the income of both their natural parent and their step-parent unless the young person is independent. This arrangement mirrors that which has been in place for the family allowance since 1993. It has obviously been a very bipartisan position over a number of years that step-parents be included in the parental means test. It ensures that assistance is targeted to those who most need it by measuring the capacity of the family to support their children. Put simply, the additional income a step-parent places the family in a much better position than a comparable sole parent family. The parental means test also recognishe did. es that some step-parents are supporting children from previous relationships. Where that happens, any child support paid out is deducted from the amount of income assessed in the youth allowance. HOLDING, Mr CLYDE

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: ADDITIONAL RESPONSES
text: On indulgence, I want to say a few words about the member for Melbourne Ports, Clyde Holding. This may be the member's last day in parliament, as he will be away next week and we are not sure whether an election will be called before we return in August. As he is a long-serving member of this House, I would not like him to leave without my putting a few words on the record about his distinguished career in both this House and in the Victorian parliament. It is 36 years since Clyde Holding was elected to the Victorian parliament and 21 years since he was elected to the federal parliament. In that time, Melbourne Ports has rarely been easy for him to win. It has been held by an unstinting, good, old-fashioned community focus on the part of its local member. I cannot think of a single politician who is closer to his local community than Clyde. Having attended one or two of the farewells, I know that the people of Melbourne Ports are sad to see him go. Even while being an exemplary local member, Clyde has also nevertheless held very challenging positions during his political career. Some have been in the ministry, where he did excellent service for a very lengthy time in the Hawke government. In his previous parliamentary life, he was a distinguished Leader of the Opposition in the Victorian state parliament. As a federal parliamentary colleague arid former ministerial colleague, I pay tribute to the way that he has conducted two of his passions in political life. One has been his concern for the Aboriginal community. As the minister for Aboriginal affairs, he oversaw some very groundbreaking legislation and a number of actions which I think helped of to restore a sense of dignity and belonging to the Aboriginal community in our nation. The community is indebted to him for the things The other passion he pursued was the needs and concerns of the Australian Jewish community. He faithfully represented some of the views they hold on the issue of an inclusive nation in the way that he conducted his affairs in this place. He also consistently raised foreign policy issues in this place and elsewhere, one in particular being the state of Israel. Clyde was given the difficult portfolio of Aboriginal affairs at his own request after the 1983 election victory. As a state politician, he had participated in one of the early land rights demonstrations in Melbourne in the early 1960s over land title to Lake Tyers in South Gippsland. He was a pioneering minister in appointing the first ever Aboriginal head of the then Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Charles Perkins. His passionate commitment to Aboriginal land rights suffered heavy weather throughout his time as Aboriginal affairs minister. He was part of a long struggle on that issue, which was rewarded ultimately in the Native Title Act and the decision of the High Court which initially underpinned it. Clyde has been a passionate politician. He has taken up critical issues in this place, whether they happened to be popular or not. He has sought throughout his life to see every Australian citizen feel a sense of comfort and have an opportunity for creativity in the nation in which he or she lives. He will be a person long remembered in this place by those of us who have had the privilege to serve with him. He will be a person long remembered by his Labor Party colleagues in Victoria as a faithful servant in the very toughest of times. I reflect on Clyde as a man who taught me a very great deal in my early political career. He set on the odd occasion examples that oppositions might follow at the federal level, including one description of a process that he used called 'going to the mattresses'. This is not available to us under the standing orders in this place. Nevertheless, the standing orders permitted that sort of filibustering activity in Victoria. When there were key issues of community concern, he was able to use the Victorian parliament to send a level of concern right down to the wire. So he is a person who has made a real contribution to Australian life. He has had the opportunities given to him to make that contribution, and he has seized everyone of them.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: ADDITIONAL RESPONSES
text: On indulgence, I support the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley). In so doing, I would not want to validate any theories about the timing of the next electoral contest in Australia. Out of courtesy and friendship towards the member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), I record the obvious fact that, whenever the election next takes place, he is not offering himself as a candidate for the Australian Labor Party in Melbourne Ports. When that election comes, he will be leaving us. The member for Melbourne Ports has been a great servant of his party. He fought as Leader of the Opposition in Victoria at the time of the long ascendancy of the Liberal Party, first under Sir Henry Bolte and then under Dick Hamer and, ultimately, Lindsay Thompson. It was not an easy time for the Labor Party, just as historically there have not been easy times on our sides of politics. But these things happen in the history of both sides of politics. To have been a leader of the opposition in Victoria for the Labor Party at the time was certainly not a time that perhaps he would have chosen had he had some say in the time that he entered the political scene. But 36 years of public life is a long time, and I think it is important-at a time when the institution of parliament and the contribution of what is now in the modern colloquium called mainstream political parties is under constant derision and attack-that, on occasions, there be a defence of the contributions on both sides undertaken by people on both sides. On behalf of the coalition parties, I want to compliment Clyde Holding on the contribution that he has made to public life in Victoria and in Australia. I know he has had some great passions. He has been very closely identified in his public life, as I have, with the Jewish community of Australia, and I know the depth of his feeling on the state of Israel and the interests of Jewish people all around the world. It is a sentiment that I feel very strongly about, and I identify very strongly with the views that he has expressed on that subject. Of course, the member and I do not share all that many views in common politically, but I have always seen him as a tough fighter for his cause and as somebody who has worked very hard for his community. I remember very well a conversation I had with him as we both walked out the door over there-I think it was in 1991; it was around the time of the first contest between Mr Hawke and' Mr Keating for the leadership of the Labor Party-when each of us was reflecting on our years in politics. He remarked to me then how he had found, despite the fact that he was no longer on the front bench of the then government, a great deal of peace and contentment in representing his constituents. He found a great deal of satisfaction in simply putting their cause. He thought that there was a place in this parliament for people who saw their career beyond any particular office in a party but simply in terms of public service. So, Mr Speaker, I would not want the opportunity to go by without recording my respects for him and for his contribution to public life. I would not like to speculate as to how many more times I will see him sitting over there-I simply make no comment on that-but, lest it were thought there was any lack of charity on our side in relation to people who had made a contribution to their party, whatever that party may be, I want to associate myself with the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition. Honourable members-Hear, hear!

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: ADDITIONAL RESPONSES
text: I thank both the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for their more than generous comments. I must say I have enjoyed my life in politics. Thirty-six years is a long time. I take some pride, I might say, in the fact that I have never actually been thrown out of either parliament, and that requires some skill over 36 years.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADDITIONAL RESPONSES
text: That can always be corrected!

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: ADDITIONAL RESPONSES
text: If I might give a hint to some of my younger colleagues, the English language provides a great facility in its width to malign your opponents, and if you use the right words you can get away with it. The reason I say that is that there are some highly offensive words in the English language, but they are rarely used-or rarely used commonly. Time and again I have been able to use those words with the confidence, because they are so rarely used, that nobody takes any objection. So, for younger members, I suggest you go to the English dictionary and develop that facility. I must say one of the things that I find disturbing about this parliament as an institution is that it has none of the capacity, in many ways-except when perhaps members go on parliamentary delegations or are working together on committees-for the sort of genuine camaraderie which never interfered with political ideals that existed in the Old Parliament House. It is going to be a long time, I feel, before we ever see again the kind of relationship that developed between Jim Killen and Fred Daly. I think that is sad because, in my time in parliament, irrespective of people's ideological or political beliefs, the average member really comes into the parliament highly motivated in terms of trying to create a better society, whether that is in the state parliament or not. The state parliament enabled all sorts of relationships to develop, and confidences were made and confidences were kept. I had a relationship with Henry Bolte which meant that, as a result of one fairly late night office, I knew before any member of his own party of his intended resignation. He did not feel any difficulty with telling me because he knew that a confidence would be kept-and it was kept. There were many occasions, because of the intimacy of a smaller parliament, when people were able to reach out to each other across the political divide. I think the very size of this parliament is such that that becomes more difficult. I remember early on in state parliament I was checking the Hansard-my own speech, I might say-and that old veteran of the Senate in this parliament, Pat Kennelly, walked in and said, 'Wh-wh-what are you dd-doing?' I said, 'I'm checking the Hansard' . He said, 'D-d-don't w-w-waste your t-t-time. Hansard w-w-will always m-m-make a b-bbetter speech for you th-th-than you m-mmake yourself.' I must say I have found that true. I would like to record my thanks to Hansard and, indeed, to all members of the staff of this parliament. We do not realise to what extent they do a job for us, always with unfailing courtesy and with deep regard. I extend thanks to the great facility that is available to all members as a result of the library service, which I think is without parallel anywhere in Australia. If properly used, it makes life a lot easier for all of us. I would also like to say this: one of the experiences I have had on the Human Rights Committee of Parliamentarians for the IPU is to understand how lucky we are in Australia to be the beneficiaries of the Westminster system. Whatever the dialogue that goes on in strong terms across this chamber, none of us ever fear that we are going to be subject to arbitrary arrest. There are currently some 200 democratically elected members of parliaments who are in gaol. From one view, they have done better than those who have been subject to political assassination. Whatever view you might take about the republic, one of the great contributions the British have handed down to us is the Westminster system. We should never devalue it; it is absolutely integral to the way this society advances. I am pleased to have been honoured to be in this parliament. Some portfolios you enjoy in his more than others. I have never regretted having asked for the portfolio of Aboriginal affairs. Indeed, one of the better experiences in my life is that I and my family in fact have skin with two Aboriginal communities, and that is a very important factor at a family level. I wish all members of this parliament well in the future. You will not mind if I am a little biased and say that I wish my own colleagues good luck in the near future. I have enjoyed my time here, and I value the experience that I have had. I commend this institution to all Australians, because without it we would be a lesser people. I believe that most members here, indeed all members here, have a commitment to the welfare of their fellow citizens which I think will take this parliament into the future and serve the Australian people well. Honourable members-Hear, hear!

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADDITIONAL RESPONSES
text: I would like to add my own remarks and say to the honourable member for Melbourne Ports that I have enjoyed his company, I have enjoyed his contributions and, above all, I respect the role he is now playing representing all parliamentarians around the world on the committee to which he just referred. As many may not know, Clyde is the Chairman of the InterParliamentary Union Human Rights Committee of Parliamentarians and, as such, has a particular role in trying to ensure that those to whom he referred are recognised and to a degree protected. I wish both Clyde and his family, Judy and Isabella, well, and we all appreciate the years we have served together. NA

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Last night the ABC TV news published a surgically selective quote from myself which, when taken in isolation, completely misrepresented my position on the proposed Melbourne to Darwin railway project. My opening remark to the doorstop interview selectively broadcast did question the general financial viability of major general freight-rail networks, but it was followed by words that said that as this project was being promoted and investigated by private enterprise with private enterprise money, it should therefore be supported by all Australians. Furthermore, I subsequently issued a written media release at 10 a.m. on Wednesday, 24 June 1998, some nine hours before the TV screening which said in part: A respectable Australian Company announces a feasibility study into a major private infrastructure project and instead of welcoming that Company's initiative the Australian media chooses to concentrate on political conspiracy theories, Wilson Tuckey, Federal Member for O'Connor said today. The efforts of the ABC editors to selectively quote from my interview in this fashion and ignore my press release is just further evidence of the bias emanating from that organisation.
